1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:41): even far to be a niche problem‚Ä¶ it's one of the first questions I get when talking about mediaqueries for background images. "OH cool!!! How can I use it for img too?"
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:44): different images for different screen resolutions? uh, no...
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:45): for different screen sizes vs. dpi, perhaps
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:47): lowsrc is not enough
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:48): you need to be able to select the screen size.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:48): screen size is meaningless without dpi as well
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:49): (and even then is only meaningful on mobile browsers, not on anything where the window size is variable)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:49): (technically the window size is variable on android's browser, but)
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:50): has a tendency to resize his windows on desktop to get the mediaqueries for small screens. Better sites usually.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:51): i always use maximized browsers, myself

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:54): heh, this is also one of the rare cases where progressive jpeg could have been useful, if it was possible for browsers to request the number of passes to download
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (17:55): so it could download however much is needed for the resolution it's actually displaying at (and then resume the download to get more, if that changes)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:58): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167, if you are already talking in the context of images it's not surprising the question comes up
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:58): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: not sure how does it relate to what we are saying.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:58): contextual images is a **need**, not a niche problem, and a growing frustration from designers.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:58): it is already implemented and well used for background-images in CSS
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:58): people want it for img element
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:59): what's wrong with using a high-resolution image?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:59): It has nothing to do with the resolution

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:01): for example, contextual images are an image where you would have a "Logo + company name" (let's say a 400 pixels banner) then when you reach a smaller screen, you want to display only the logo without the company name, (like a 100px square logo)
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:01): It is just an example.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:02): a thumbnail of an image at a small size is not necessary the full image but a crop of the bigger image.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (18:02): i'd think you'd just have two images in that case, toggled on mutually exclusively with css, not a single image with src magic
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:02): like for example a rectangle image and you show a square crop at smaller size
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:02): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: you are not forced to limit yourself to two images
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (18:03): yes, you can have three or four images, again with visibility controlled with css :)
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:03): because you can precisely target a very large screen, a tablet screen, a giant billboard, a desktop screen, etc.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (18:03): (not ideal, since it won't work well if the stylesheet isn't loaded, but "css is optional" doesn't exactly work in practice very often anyway heh)
afb0216dbb5a9709eab37eaa5a4422eb (18:03): thinks this would be great for targeting mobile vs. full screen

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (18:06): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: what i'm saying is, why do this with a complex <img> mechanism, instead of implementing it with multiple, distinct <img> nodes, controlling visibility on each (whether with css or otherwise)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:07): <img> is already way complex, adding some conditional resource loading on top of it used by a couple of authors is not worth it
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:08): I think characterising it as :a couple of authors" is not very fair
